entry.et: Middle English, alteration (influenced by either) of nauther, nother, from Old English nāhwæther, nōther, from nā, nō not + hwæther which of two, whether

def.dt: :not either neither black nor white
:also not neither did I

entry.pt: Although use with or is neither archaic nor wrong, neither is usually followed by nor. A few commentators think that neither must be limited in reference to two, but reference to more than two has been quite common since the 17th century rigid enforcement of antique decorum will help neither language, literature, nor literati James Sledd.

def.dt: :not the one or the other of two or more

entry.pt: Some commentators insist that neither must be used with a singular verb. It generally is, but especially when a prepositional phrase intervenes between it and the verb, a plural verb is quite common neither of those ideal solutions are in sight C. P. Snow.

def.dt: :not either neither hand
:either
:similarly not :also not just as the serf was not permitted to leave the land, so neither was his offspring G. G. Coulton

art.capt: fish 1b: 1 mandible, 2 nasal opening, 3 eye, 4 cheek, 5 operculum, 6 dorsal fins, 7 lateral line, 8 caudal fin, 9 scales, 10 anal fin, 11 anus, 12 pectoral fin, 13 pelvic fin, 14 maxilla, 15 premaxilla, 16 upper jaw

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English fisc; akin to Old High German fisc fish, Latin piscis

def.dt: :an aquatic animal usually used in combination starfish cuttlefish

:any of numerous cold-blooded strictly aquatic craniate vertebrates that include the bony fishes and usually the cartilaginous and jawless fishes and that have typically an elongated somewhat spindle-shaped body terminating in a broad caudal fin, limbs in the form of fins when present at all, and a 2-chambered heart by which blood is sent through thoracic gills to be oxygenated
:the flesh of fish used as food
:a person who is caught or is wanted (as in a criminal investigation)
:fellow person an odd fish
:sucker 5a
:something that resembles a fish: as
:pisces 1
:pisces 2a
:torpedo 2b
:a person who is in an unnatural or uncomfortable sphere or situation
:concerns or interests to pursue usually used with other
:one that does not belong to a particular class or category

art.cap: fish 2a: 1 mandible, 2 nasal opening, 3 eye, 4 cheek, 5 operculum, 6 dorsal fins, 7 lateral line, 8 caudal fin, 9 scales, 10 anal fin, 11 anus, 12 pectoral fin, 13 pelvic fin, 14 maxilla, 15 premaxilla, 16 upper jaw

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hēr; akin to Old High German hier here, Old English hē he

def.dt: :in or at this place turn here often used interjectionally especially in answering a roll call
:now here it's morning already
:in an arbitrary location a book here, a paper there
:at or in this point, particular, or case here we agree
:in the present life or state
:hither come here

dt.un: used interjectionally in rebuke or encouragement
used interjectionally to express resolution or resignation especially at the beginning of a difficult or unpleasant undertaking

def.dt: :having no interest or relevance :of no consequence comfort is neither here nor there to a real sailor
